chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management
chapter.summary: Covers the management of a person with pruritus ani, including how to assess the person and when to arrange referral.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 1 month onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with pruritus ani?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Take a detailed history to identify a secondary cause for the itch. Ask about:
    • The duration and pattern of the itch, including whether:
      • It occurs mainly at night — possible threadworm infestation. See the CKS topic on Threadworm for more information.
      • There are household contacts affected — possible scabies infestation. See the CKS topic on Scabies for more information.
      • The itch is related to trigger factors, such as certain clothing, stresses, or foods. 
    • The severity of the itch and the impact on mood, sleep pattern, and social life.
    • Hygiene practices, including washing regimen and the use of creams, perfumes, or soaps — possible contact dermatitis or atopic eczema. See the CKS topics on Dermatitis - contact and Eczema - atopic for more information.
    • The presence of 'red flags' for anorectal cancer, such as symptoms (for example altered bowel habits) or a family history. See the CKS topic on Gastrointestinal tract (lower) cancers - recognition and referral for detailed information on when to suspect anal or colorectal cancer.
    • Other symptoms experienced:
      • Perianal pain may be due to an anal fissure or haemorrhoids. See the CKS topics on Anal fissure and Haemorrhoids for more information.
      • Rectal bleeding may be due to haemorrhoids or anorectal cancer. See the CKS topics on Haemorrhoids and Gastrointestinal tract (lower) cancers - recognition and referral for more information.
      • Anal discharge may be due to infection, infestation, or haemorrhoids.
      • Irritability, sleep disturbance, and decreased appetite may be seen in children who are too young to scratch.
  • Examine the person. Offer the option of a chaperone. Ask them to lie comfortably in a lateral position, and gently part the buttocks. 
    • An external examination may reveal the cause of the itch (for example haemorrhoids, anal fissure, or perianal eczema).
    • The appearance of the perianal skin will vary depending on the intensity and duration of pruritus ani:
      • In mild cases, there may be minimal erythema.
      • In severe cases, the skin may be inflamed, excoriated, and/or fissured.
      • In chronic cases, the anal ring may have a shiny appearance, and there may be lichenification of the skin due to repeated scratching.
    • Perform a digital rectal examination in adults (if this is possible without causing pain) to exclude any underlying pathology, such as a perianal mass suggesting anorectal cancer.
  • If no cause for the itch is identified, primary (idiopathic) pruritus ani is likely. 
  • Investigations are usually not needed in primary care unless an underlying condition is suspected.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• These recommendations are based on expert opinion in review articles [Siddiqi, Vijay, and Ward, 2008; Song and Kim, 2011; Fargo and Latimer, 2012; Summers, 2013; Foxx-Orenstein et al, 2014; Henderson and Cash, 2014; Klein, 2014; Ansari, 2016] and text books [Brown, 2014; Gaertner and Melton, 2016; Szmulowicz, 2016] on pruritus ani, which state that:
    • A careful history and physical examination of the perianal area is important for an accurate and timely diagnosis of any underlying cause of pruritus ani.
    • Identifying a cause will allow appropriate management of the underlying problem.
    • Healthcare professionals should have a high index of suspicion for malignant conditions, and people with 'red flags' for lower gastrointestinal cancer should be referred for further investigations.
    • Primary (idiopathic) pruritus ani accounts for 25–75% of pruritus ani cases, and is likely when there is no identifiable cause for the itch [Siddiqi, Vijay, and Ward, 2008; Song and Kim, 2011].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with pruritus ani?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Manage any underlying cause, where possible.
    • If anal or colorectal cancer is suspected, refer to a colorectal surgeon using the suspected cancer pathway (for an appointment within 2 weeks). See the CKS topic on Gastrointestinal tract (lower) cancers - recognition and referral for detailed information on when to suspect these conditions.
    • If an underlying cause that cannot be managed in primary care is suspected or identified, refer to an appropriate specialist (colorectal surgeon or dermatologist), the urgency depending on clinical judgement.
  • Advise on self-care measures, including:
    • Avoiding scratching, if possible. Nails should be kept short, and cotton gloves worn at night, to reduce skin trauma.
    • Maintaining good perianal hygiene. They should: 
      • Gently wash the perianal area after every bowel movement and at bedtime, where possible, using a shower jet or by sitting in the bath.
      • Gently dry the perianal area by patting with a soft towel, not by rubbing. A hair dryer on the cool setting can also be used.
      • Wear cotton underwear, avoid tight clothing, and use stockings (instead of tights), to reduce sweating or excess moisture. 
      • Avoid talcum powder, soaps, perfumed products, or deodorant around the perianal area.
      • Keep the perianal area cool at night (for example by using a light duvet or bed sheet).
    • Avoid foods and drinks known to aggravate pruritus ani. 
  • Ensure stools are formed and regular, to reduce perianal leakage. 
    • Advise adequate dietary fibre intake by eating a balanced diet containing whole grains, fruits, and vegetables; this should be done gradually to minimize flatulence and bloating. 
    • Advise that adequate (but not excessive) fluid intake is particularly important with an increased fibre diet to maintain soft, well-lubricated stools and to prevent intestinal obstruction.
    • If the person is constipated, see the CKS topics on Constipation and Constipation in children for information on management.
  • Manage any symptoms.
    • If the perianal skin is excoriated, consider prescribing a soothing cream or ointment containing bismuth subgallate or zinc oxide. See the section on Topical treatments for more information.
    • If the perianal skin is inflamed, consider prescribing a mildly potent topical corticosteroid (such as hydrocortisone 1% cream or ointment) to be used for no longer than 7 days. See the section on Topical treatments for more information.
    • If there is disturbed sleep due to nocturnal itching, consider prescribing a sedating antihistamine (such as chlorphenamine, off-label use). See the section on Prescribing information for more information.
  • Provide sources of written information and advice on self-care, such as:
    • The British Association of Dermatologists (BAD) patient information leaflet on Pruritus ani (available at www.bad.org.uk).
    • The Association of Coloproctology of Great Britain and Ireland (ACPGBI) publication on Itchy bottom (available at www.acpgbi.org.uk).
  • Advise that in most people with pruritus ani, symptoms will resolve with self-care measures and symptomatic treatment. 
    • It is reasonable to gradually relax self-care measures after 2 months, if symptoms have settled. If symptoms recur, the regimen can be restarted.
    • If symptoms do not settle with self-care measures and symptomatic treatment after 3–6 weeks, consider the need for investigations, depending on clinical judgement, such as:
      • A full blood count.
      • Ferritin levels.
      • HbA1c.
      • Thyroid function tests.
    • If no cause is identified, refer the person to a colorectal surgeon to exclude an anorectal pathology.
      • If no anorectal cause is found, specialists may consider alternative treatment options for refractory pruritus ani (such as intradermal injection of methylene blue).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Managing any underlying cause, where possible
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in review articles [Song and Kim, 2011; Fargo and Latimer, 2012; Summers, 2013; Foxx-Orenstein et al, 2014; Ansari, 2016] and textbooks [Gaertner and Melton, 2016; Szmulowicz, 2016] on pruritus ani, which state that the treatment of pruritus ani should be directed toward identifying and managing any underlying cause. 
    • Expert opinion in a review article is that most cases of secondary pruritus ani improve after the causative factor has been managed [Song and Kim, 2011].
  • The recommendation to refer to a colorectal surgeon using the suspected cancer pathway if anal or colorectal cancer is suspected is based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Suspected cancer: recognition and referral [NICE, 2015].
  • The recommendation to refer to an appropriate specialist if an underlying cause that cannot be managed in primary care is suspected or identified is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice and is supported by expert opinion in a review article on pruritus ani [Summers, 2013].
Self-care measures
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in review articles [Fargo and Latimer, 2012; Summers, 2013; Foxx-Orenstein et al, 2014; Ansari, 2016] and textbooks [Brown, 2014; Szmulowicz, 2016] on pruritus ani, which state that if no reversible cause for the itch is identified, simple measures (such as perianal hygiene and diet modification) should be tried.
  • The recommended self-care advice is based on expert opinion in review articles [Summers, 2013; Foxx-Orenstein et al, 2014] and textbooks [Szmulowicz, 2016; Brown, 2014] on pruritus ani.
    • Persistent scratching will often lead to persistent itching due to aggravation of inflammation [Brown, 2014; Foxx-Orenstein et al, 2014].
Maintaining regular, formed stools
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in a review article [Summers, 2013] and textbooks [Brown, 2014; Szmulowicz, 2016] on pruritus ani, which state that maintaining regular, well-formed stools will reduce straining and possible irritation to the perianal area. It will also help to improve the consistency of watery to loose stools, thereby minimizing anal leakage (a possible underlying cause of primary pruritus ani).
Symptomatic relief
  • For people with excoriated perianal skin
    • The recommendation to consider using a bland protective or soothing ointment or cream containing bismuth subgallate and/or zinc oxide is based on expert opinion in review articles [Chaudhry and Bastawrous, 2003; Ansari, 2016] and textbooks [Gaertner and Melton, 2016; Szmulowicz, 2016] on pruritus ani. 
  • For people with inflamed perianal skin
    • The recommendation to consider using a mildly potent topical corticosteroid is based on expert opinion in review articles [Fargo and Latimer, 2012; Summers, 2013; Foxx-Orenstein et al, 2014; Ansari, 2016] and textbooks [Gaertner and Melton, 2016; Szmulowicz, 2016] on pruritus ani. 
      • Topical corticosteroids will help to stop the itch-scratch cycle by reducing inflammation [Szmulowicz, 2016].
    • For people with disturbed sleep due to nocturnal itching
      • The recommendation to consider using a sedating antihistamine is based on expert opinion in a review article on pruritus ani [Summers, 2013].  
      • Although chlorphenamine is not specifically licensed for pruritus ani, it is licensed for the management of allergic conditions, including urticaria (where itch is the predominant symptom) [ABPI, 2016a].
Providing sources of written information
  • This recommendation is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Considering the need for investigations if symptoms do not settle after 3–6 weeks of conservative treatment
  • This recommendation is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice, considering that pruritus ani may be caused by systemic diseases, such as kidney or liver disease, leukaemia, lymphoma, anaemia (aplastic or iron deficiency), diabetes mellitus, and thyroid disease [Siddiqi, Vijay, and Ward, 2008; Song and Kim, 2011; Brown, 2014; Foxx-Orenstein et al, 2014; Ansari, 2016; Szmulowicz, 2016].
Referral if symptoms do not resolve
  • The recommendation to refer to a colorectal surgeon if symptoms do not settle with self-care measures and symptomatic treatment after 3–6 weeks is based on expert opinion in a review article (which recommends referral if symptoms persist after 2–3 weeks of conservative treatment) [Song and Kim, 2011] and a textbook (which recommends referral if symptoms persist after 4–6 weeks of conservative treatment) [Gaertner and Melton, 2016].
  • The information on secondary care treatment for refractory pruritus ani is based on expert opinion in a review article [Song and Kim, 2011].
